economic_context.details: Multiple disputes over labor and payment: (1) quarrel over equal share for threshing when he did less work than others; (2) payment dispute over horse exchange; (3) son Demenge feared Jean would not pay for hay; (4) termination of ploughing/sowing partnership. Jean's poverty evident in: fear of wife's anger over not working hard enough, inability to pay for hay, desperate attempts to secure equal payment despite less work. Accused wife described as 'rioteuse' who beat his son - domestic tensions related to economic stress. Judge mentioned Jean disposing of goods and absenting himself before arrest.

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a well-documented trial with clear chronology and detailed witness testimony. Key uncertainties: (1) Jean's second wife's name unclear - called 'rioteuse' and addressed as 'Chrestienne' by one witness, but may not be same person; (2) Economic status assessed as 'poor' based on multiple payment disputes, fear of non-payment, wife's criticism about not working hard enough, and judges' mention of disposing goods before arrest; (3) Some relationship details unclear - whether Barbon's brother who was executed is same person mentioned or different; (4) Confession came under threat of torture (while being shaved by executioner) rather than actual torture application; (5) The 'strange light' incident (witness 16) is unusual testimony about possible supernatural phenomenon; (6) Jean showed some resistance to devil's demands (wore blessed bread, objected to making hail because of his children) which is notable psychological detail; (7) His defense strategy included aggressive counter-accusations of theft and sexual immorality against witnesses.
